thread.title: Carnival Cruise Line relaxes policy on bring-your-own beverages
thread.title_full: Carnival Cruise Line relaxes policy on bring-your-own beverages

title: Carnival Cruise Line relaxes policy on bring-your-own beverages
text:
Carnival Cruise Line's newest ship, the Carnival Breeze. (Photo: Peter Knego)
8 CONNECT 3 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Cruise giant Carnival has scored some cool points with customers by loosening its restrictions on bring-your-own beverages.
The line has lifted a ban on passengers carrying sodas and other non-alcoholic drinks on board vessels after port calls as long as the beverages are in cans or cartons of 12 or fewer ounces. A ban on bottled beverages will remain in place.
Until now passengers only were allowed to carry non-alcoholic beverages onto ships at the start of a voyage.
USA TODAY
Carnival to ban carry-on bottled beverages
A caveat: Passengers will be allowed to bring a maximum of 12 cans or cartons per person aboard a ship at a time.
For a look inside a Carnival vessel, scroll through the carousels below.
Carnival Cruises’ 70,367 gt, 855-by-103-foot, 2,052-guest Carnival Imagination is currently home-ported in Long Beach, CA, offering three and four night cruises to Ensenada, Mexico and Catalina Island. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Imagination entered service as the Imagination in 1995 and was the fifth in a series of eight Fantasy-Class “Superliners”. It was christened by Jodi Dickinson, wife of then-Carnival President and CEO Bob Dickinson. Peter Knego Fullscreen The ship, AKA Hull Number 488, was built at a cost of $330 million by Kvaerner Masa shipyards in Helsinki, Finland, which is now part of the STX-Europe franchise. Peter Knego Fullscreen Shown here in its original guise as the Imagination (the Carnival prefix was added to the ship’s name in 2007), the Carnival Imagination is manned by an international crew of 920. The ship is powered by six medium speed Warsila diesels that achieve 50,000 BHP to drive twin screws at a service speed of 21 knots. Peter Knego Fullscreen Fully air conditioned and stabilized, the Carnival Imagination has ten passenger decks. Peter Knego Fullscreen Topping the ship is the 300-foot Twister waterslide, which is reached via a spiral staircase on the port side of aft Sports Deck (12). A trio of slides comprise a water park that was added in the ship’s $40 million “Evolutions of Fun” refit in 2007. Peter Knego Fullscreen A medium length “race slide” can be accessed from the starboard side of aft Sports Deck (12). There is also a third slide for toddlers. Peter Knego Fullscreen The City Sports Park is located on forward Sun Deck (14) and contains ping pong, a nine hole mini-golf course and a jogging track that runs through the base of the radio mast. Peter Knego Fullscreen This is an aft-facing view of the City Sports Park, which is sheltered from high winds by glass screens forward and along either side. Peter Knego Fullscreen A narrow terrace at the forward end of Sun Deck (14) is open to the elements and offers spectacular views over the ship’s bow. Peter Knego Fullscreen The jogging track continues aft from the City Sports Park and encircles the skylight that tops the seven-deck-tall Grand Atrium. There is a small sunning terrace at the aft end of Sun Deck. Peter Knego Fullscreen From Sun Deck, there is a great view of the midships lido and pool area. Peter Knego Fullscreen Inspired by an airplane’s tail and, no doubt, the winged funnels of the SS France ocean liner of 1961, all Carnival ships boast fluted smokestacks that emit exhausts to the side of the ship. This is a view of the Carnival Imagination’s funnel from aft Sports Deck (12). Peter Knego Fullscreen At the forward end of Verandah Deck (11), there is another observation platform that extends to either side of the ship from atop the bridge. Peter Knego Fullscreen This is a view facing aft from the port side of the Verandah Deck observation platform. Peter Knego Fullscreen The midships portion of Verandah Deck (11) overlooks the pool area with a walkway and sunning terraces that continue aft to a large sunning area near the base of the funnel. Peter Knego Fullscreen The far aft portion of Verandah Deck (11) contains the water park and another open sunning space. Peter Knego Fullscreen Lido Deck (10) begins with finite, teak-lined promenades on either side. Like the great ocean liners of yore, the Fantasy Class ships boast acres of beautifully maintained teak decking. Peter Knego Fullscreen The sheltered Poolside Bars are located at the forward end of the midships pool on Lido (10) Deck. Peter Knego Fullscreen The midships portion of Lido Deck (10) has a long pool with deep and shallow sections, two Jacuzzis, a large, elevated bandstand, open sunning space and shaded areas. Peter Knego Fullscreen The adults-only Serenity, as seen from Verandah Deck, is located on aft Promenade Deck (9) and contains open and sheltered deck space as well as a Jacuzzi. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Fantasy Class ships were built when awe-inspiring shipboard atria were very much in vogue. The Carnival Imagination’s Grand Atrium spans seven decks and is considered the heart of the ship. Peter Knego Fullscreen As built, the Grand Atrium featured a large steel and glass kinetic sculpture by Leonard Janklow. Peter Knego Fullscreen In 2007, the sculpture was replaced with the 10-seat Lobby Bar. Peter Knego Fullscreen The original multi-faceted marble, glass and steel detailing of the Grand Atrium remains. Peter Knego Fullscreen The 12,000-square-foot Carnival Spa is located at the forward end of Sports Deck (12). Peter Knego Fullscreen A fully equipped beauty salon is accessed from the starboard side of the Carnival Spa. Peter Knego Fullscreen Spa guests can visit the relaxation room before and after treatments. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Spa has several private treatment rooms offering a wide array of skin and massage therapies. Peter Knego Fullscreen This is a couple’s treatment room. Peter Knego Fullscreen Men’s (shown) and Women’s changing and steam areas are located on the port and starboard side of the Spa, respectively. Peter Knego Fullscreen This is the Men’s steam room in the Carnival Spa. Peter Knego Fullscreen This is the Men’s sauna in the Carnival Spa. Peter Knego Fullscreen A large gymnasium is located at the forward end of the Carnival Spa, offering numerous cardio machines, weight machines and free weights. Peter Knego Fullscreen Adjacent to the gymnasium, there is an aerobics and stretching area. Peter Knego Fullscreen Camp Carnival is a children’s playroom on Verandah Deck (11) near the Grand Atrium. One of three youth centers, it has specific activities for kids aged 2 -- 5; 6 -- 8; and 9 -- 11 years old. Peter Knego Fullscreen Aft of the midships pool area on Lido (11) Deck, there is the casual, 722-seat Horizon Bar and Grill, the forward portion of which houses the Rotisserie and the Mongolian Wok (shown). Peter Knego Fullscreen The popular Mongolian Wok has a selection of veggies and noodles guests can choose from to make their custom meal. Peter Knego Fullscreen At the Mongolian Wok, a choice of three sauces (Szechuan, Black Bean or Thai BBQ) are blended with the veggies and noodles, then cooked with chicken, beef, shrimp or a combination thereof. Peter Knego Fullscreen Other dining choices in the Horizon Bar, which has both indoor and outdoor seating, include a Pizzeria, New York-Style Deli, a Grill, a Salad Bar, an International Station (Italian, Indian, etc.) and Desserts. Peter Knego Fullscreen The largest public room on the Carnival Imagination is the double deck Dynasty Show Lounge at the forward end of Promenade (9) and Atlantic (8) Decks. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Dynasty Show Lounge seats 1,300 guests. It features custom designed soft fittings, brass, simulated pear wood trim and Venetian glass mosaic-topped tables designed by former Carnival marine architect Joseph Farcus. Peter Knego Fullscreen Aft of the showroom on the starboard side of Promenade Deck (9), there is the Pixels photo gallery. Peter Knego Fullscreen Directly across the Grand Atrium on the port side of Promenade Deck (9) from Pixels, there is a video arcade called Virtual Reality. Peter Knego Fullscreen Conveniently adjacent to the Virtual Reality video arcade is Club 02, which caters to teens aged 15 -- 17 with games, a disco, and lounge area. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Taste Bar, added in 2012, is a complimentary appetizer bar located aft of the Grand Atrium on the starboard side of Promenade Deck (9) at the forward end of the Imagination Promenade. Peter Knego Fullscreen The 230-seat Imagination Promenade is a wide walkway on the starboard side of Promenade Deck (9) that connects several of the ship’s public rooms. Its fiber-optic lighting, pulsating neon, Venetian glass mosaics and wide swaths of marble are classic Carnival design elements. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Imagination’s decorative theme was inspired by “the imagination of people of the past” and is still evident in the Luxor-inspired sphinxes that line the Imagination Promenade. Peter Knego Fullscreen Probably no ships afloat can out dazzle the eye-popping neons of the Fantasy class ships. The 450-capacity El Dorado Casino is possibly the most vivid of the Carnival Imagination’s public rooms. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Dream Bar is located on the Imagination Promenade adjacent to the El Dorado Casino. Peter Knego Fullscreen This is the aft portion of the El Dorado Casino in a forward-facing view. Peter Knego Fullscreen All Carnival ships now have a candy shop for those with an insatiable sweet tooth. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Shangri-La Lounge seats 109 and is accessed via the Imagination Promenade. Its decorative elements are inspired by classical forms used in Renaissance architecture. Peter Knego Fullscreen Located on the promenade between the entrances to Shangri-La and the Illusions Nightclub, Vittorio’s Cafe is the ship’s specialty coffee venue and patisserie. Fees apply. Peter Knego Fullscreen Illusions Nightclub seats 230 guests and features prismatic metal wall units, lacquered surfacing, tivoli lighting and polished stone. Peter Knego Fullscreen A garment shop is located at the aft end of the Imagination Promenade. Peter Knego Fullscreen This is a forward facing view from the aft section of the Imagination Promenade. Peter Knego Fullscreen A Conference Room on the port side of Promenade Deck (9) can be used for weddings, meetings and corporate functions. Peter Knego Fullscreen The 92-seat Pinnacle Club is located on Promenade Deck at the far aft end of the Imagination Promenade. Its outer sections offer views of the sea through full length windows. Peter Knego Fullscreen In the center portion of the Pinnacle Club, there is a large bar. Venetian crystal chandeliers hover over stairs that lead down to the Spirit Dining Room. This is the ship’s designated cigar-smoking area. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Xanadu Lounge is a cabaret style showroom that doubles as the Punchliner Comedy Club and seats 541 guests at the aft end of Promenade Deck (9). Winged silver busts of Mercury atop bases of simulated Macassar ebony are its main decorative focal points. Peter Knego Fullscreen Directly aft of the Dynasty Show Lounge on Atlantic Deck (8), there are two large duty free Fun Shops. Peter Knego Fullscreen Circle C is a tween center for those aged 12 -- 14 and features TV screens, a dance floor and computer games. It is located on the port side of Atlantic Deck (8) off the Grand Atrium. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Mirage Bar seats 92 and can be accessed from the Atlantic Deck (8) level of the Grand Atrium. This “have a ball”-themed piano bar features fiber-optic orb lighting and eye-popping purple and yellow spheres that appear to be suspended mid-air. Peter Knego Fullscreen Adjacent to the Mirage Bar is the 43-seat Curiosity Library, which combines the Bernini columns of St. Peters with antique European cabinetry and Persian Rugs underneath stained glass, star-shaped ceiling fixtures. Peter Knego Fullscreen The first of two nearly identical dining rooms on Atlantic Deck, the 650-seat Pride, is named for (Carnival-owned) Seabourn Cruise Line’s deluxe MV Seabourn Pride. The central section is slightly raised. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Pride Dining Room has full length windows on each side and boasts vivid fiber-optic tivoli lighting. “Your Time” dining can be enjoyed here at the guests’ leisure between 5:45 and 9:30 PM. Peter Knego Fullscreen The aft-situated Spirit Dining Room can be accessed via the marble and brass staircase in the Pinnacle Club on Promenade Deck (8). Peter Knego Fullscreen The Spirit Dining Room is named for the Seabourn Spirit cruise ship and accommodates 658 guests for fixed dinner seatings at 6:00 and 8:15 PM. Peter Knego Fullscreen At the bottom level of the Grand Atrium on Empress Deck (7) on the starboard side, there is a 24-hour Guest Services Desk. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Shore Excursions Desk is directly across from the Guest Services Desk Peter Knego Fullscreen Directly aft of the Grand Atrium on Empress Deck (7), the midships passage contains an art gallery. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Imagination has two self-service, coin-operated laundrettes on forward Empress (shown) and midships Upper Decks. Peter Knego Fullscreen Although there are two sprawling owner’s suites overlooking the Grand Atrium on Sports Deck (12), the Carnival Imagination’s largest advertised staterooms are twenty eight 400-square-foot Grand Suites on midships Upper Deck (6). Peter Knego Fullscreen Due to their proximity to the sea, Grand Suites have a balcony that is built into the hull. Peter Knego Fullscreen Grand Suites also have small walk-in closets. Peter Knego Fullscreen Grand Suite bathrooms are fitted with marble-topped counters and whirlpool tubs with shower. Peter Knego Fullscreen Twenty six Junior Suites measure 250-square-feet and are located at the top of the ship on Verandah Deck (11). Peter Knego Fullscreen This is a Junior Suite Balcony. Note open railing versus the steel wall on the Grand Suite balconies. Peter Knego Fullscreen Carnival Imagination has 564 Ocean View staterooms with picture windows. These popular cabins measure 185-square-feet. Peter Knego Fullscreen Other than Grand Suites and handicap-access staterooms, all cabins on board the Carnival Imagination have similar modular bathrooms with shower, sink and toilet. Peter Knego Fullscreen There are 389 Interior Twins on the Carnival Imagination that measure 185-square-feet. All staterooms have twin beds that can convert to kings. Peter Knego Fullscreen Handicap access staterooms have modified bathrooms with roll-in showers and folding seats. Peter Knego Fullscreen There are 19 Upper/Lower Interior staterooms that measure 185-square-feet. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Imagination is nearing twenty years of service with Carnival and represents one of the most successful and popular cruise ship platforms to date. Peter Knego The 2004-built Carnival Miracle is the fourth in Carnival Cruise Line’s four-member Spirit Class platform, which also includes the 2001-built Carnival Spirit and Carnival Pride and the 2002-built Carnival Legend. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Miracle was built by the Kvaerner Masa Shipyard (hull number 503) at Helsinki, Finland. Originally founded as Wartsila, and recently called Aker Finnyards, it is now operating as STX Finland. Peter Knego Fullscreen Sailing year-round on cruises to Mexico and Hawaii, Carnival Miracle is based in Long Beach, California, home to the historic former Cunard Line ocean liner Queen Mary. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Spirit Class ships are immediately distinguished by the glass-framed bases of their trademark winged Carnival funnels. Peter Knego Fullscreen The 88,500-gt, 2,124-guest Carnival MIracle measures 963-by-106-feet and is powered by six diesel engines that drive two Azipods at a service speed of 22 knots. Peter Knego Fullscreen After a major refit in 2015 at the BAE Systems Drydock in San Francisco, the Carnival Miracle now boasts many of Carnival’s newly implemented 2.0 venues like the Alchemy Bar, Redfrog Pub and Skybox sports bar. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Miracle has twelve passenger decks, beginning at the top with an observation platform at the base of the ship’s funnel on Sky Deck (12). Peter Knego Fullscreen Deck 12 overlooks the midships Sports Deck (11) sunning area. Peter Knego Fullscreen The forward portion of Deck 11 is sheltered from high winds by glass panels . Peter Knego Fullscreen Forward Deck 11 features a jogging track (15.2 laps equals a mile), a basketball court and a nine hole putting course. Peter Knego Fullscreen From forward Deck 11, there is an excellent view of the Sirens and Ulysses pool areas. Peter Knego Fullscreen On midships Deck 11, there is a wide, open deck space. Peter Knego Fullscreen The aft portion of Deck 11 has a children’s wading pool and outdoor play area. Peter Knego Fullscreen At the aft end of Deck 11, there is the 72-foot, double-loop Twister water slide. Peter Knego Fullscreen Sun Deck (10) begins with a glassed in observation platform that continues aft with sunning platforms that overlook the midships pools. Peter Knego Fullscreen The aft portion of Deck 10 is lined in teak wood. Peter Knego Fullscreen Lido Deck (9) begins with an open observation platform overlooking the bow. Peter Knego Fullscreen There is an impressive aft-facing view from the open wings atop the bridge on Deck 9. Peter Knego Fullscreen The open-air Sirens Pool area features a large Jacuzzi, fresh water showers and a bronze sculpture depicting the mermaid-like Sirens from Greek mythology. Peter Knego Fullscreen Al fresco seating from the buffet dining venue Horatio’s occupies the sheltered portions of Deck 9 on either side of the Sirens and Ulysses Pool areas. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Odyssey Bar is situated between the Sirens and Ulysses Pool areas on Deck 9. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Ulysses Pool area is aft of the Sirens Pool on Deck 9 and in inclement weather can be covered with a retractable metal and glass roof. Peter Knego Fullscreen The adults-only (21 and over) Serenity area is at the aft end of Deck 9 and features a sheltered bar and lounging area. Peter Knego Fullscreen Serenity has its own pool and Jacuzzi as well as cushioned deck chairs, hammocks for two and cabanas. Peter Knego Fullscreen On Atlantic Deck (3) a wonderful teak-lined promenade stretches aft on either side to encircle the stern. When combined with the Gatsby’s Garden interior promenade, it encircles the entire deck. Peter Knego Fullscreen Located underneath the glass dome at the base of the funnel, Nick and Nora’s is the dramatically situated, 156-seat reservations-required, extra tariff ($35 per person) steakhouse aboard the Carnival Miracle. Peter Knego Fullscreen Black and white images of New York form the backdrop in Nick and Nora’s, which is perched atop the ten deck tall Metropolis Atrium. Peter Knego Fullscreen Table settings in Nick and Nora’s include Frette linens, Versace chargers, Riedel stemware and silver plate cutlery. Peter Knego Fullscreen In addition to a wide selection of steaks, lamb, lobster, a daily fish and chicken entrées, popular Nick and Nora’s courses include a caesar salad that is prepared tableside. Peter Knego Fullscreen The desserts in Nick and Nora’s run the spectrum from tiramisu and creme brulée to homemade ice creams and this delectable caramelized apple. Peter Knego Fullscreen There is a truly vertiginous view from the glass staircase that is cantilevered over the Metropolis Atrium linking the lower level of Nick and Nora’s to Horatio’s buffet dining venue. Peter Knego Fullscreen An excellent gym is located on forward Decks 10 and 9, with cardio equipment on its lowest level and terraces of exercise equipment that surround and overlook a Jacuzzi. Peter Knego Fullscreen Aft on the port side of the gym on Deck 10, there is an aerobics room that is also used for spinning classes. Peter Knego Fullscreen Carnival Miracle’s O2 Teen Center (ages 15 to 17) is on the starboard side of Deck 10. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Spa Carnival can be accessed from the forward Deck 9 stairtower lobby on the port side. Peter Knego Fullscreen There is a relaxation room at the forward end of the Spa Carnival on Deck 9. Peter Knego Fullscreen Numerous treatment rooms in the Spa Carnival offer up everything from massages and skin therapies to teeth whitening. Peter Knego Fullscreen There are separate men’s (shown) and women’s changing areas in the Spa Carnival. Peter Knego Fullscreen Each changing area in the Spa Carnival has its own Steam Room. Peter Knego Fullscreen In addition to a Steam Room, each changing area in the Spa Carnival has a Sauna. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Venus Salon is on the starboard side of Deck 9, directly across from the Spa Carnival. Peter Knego Fullscreen Horatio’s Restaurant is the Carnival Miracle’s 458-seat casual buffet dining venue on Deck 9. With a decorative nod to Horatio Hornblower, it features models of British Man-O-Wars, busts of Hornblower and the Union Jack flag. Peter Knego Fullscreen Horatio’s has food stations that include Taste of Nations (changes daily from French to Italian, American, etc.), a salad bar, Asian, a New York-style deli, a grill and a Pizzeria that makes genuine Neapolitan-style pizza. Peter Knego Fullscreen On forward Upper Deck (5), there is the Camp Carnival, which has activities for kids aged 2 - 5, 6 - 8, and 9 - 11. Peter Knego Fullscreen On forward Main Deck (4), there is the Wizard’s video arcade. Peter Knego Fullscreen Circle C, which offers facilities and activities for 11 - 15-year-olds, is next to the Wizard’s video arcade. Peter Knego Fullscreen The triple deck Phantom Show Lounge is located on forward Decks 4, 3 and 2. The Carnival Miracle’s largest entertainment venue, it seats 1,167 guests. Peter Knego Fullscreen In addition to Carnival 2.0‘s Hasbro- and Dr. Seuss-sponsored game shows and programming, the Phantom Show Room is the setting for Carnival’s lavish production shows. Peter Knego Fullscreen Gatsby’s Garden is an interior promenade that encircles the Atlantic Deck (3) level of the Phantom Show Room with seating for 52. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Ravens Library and Internet Cafe on port Deck 3 seats 23. Peter Knego Fullscreen Adjacent to the Library, Chapel and Sam’s Piano Bar, the glitzy Fountain Stairs on Deck 3 lead down to another plaza on Deck 2. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Miracle has a dedicated wedding chapel with seating for up to 30 guests on Deck 3. Peter Knego Fullscreen Inspired by the movie “Casablanca”, the 106-seat Sam’s Piano Bar on Deck 3 has colonial Moroccan decor created by longstanding former Carnival architect Joseph Farcus. Peter Knego Fullscreen Kane’s Way is an enclosed promenade area surrounding the upper level of the Fountain Stairs that seats 53 guests. Peter Knego Fullscreen Added in 2015, Cherry On Top is a candy and flower shop that is located at the forward end of the Deck 3 Yellow Brick Road shopping gallery. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Yellow Brick Road winds its way through several shops on Deck 3 that sell everything from jewelry to souvenirs and sundries. Peter Knego Fullscreen On Deck 3, a balcony runs along either side of the massive Metropolis Atrium. Peter Knego Fullscreen Pixels photo galleries are located on the port and starboard Deck 3 balconies of the Metropolis Atrium. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Gotham Lounge is aft of the Metropolis Atrium on starboard Deck 3, accommodating up to 66 guests. Peter Knego Fullscreen Adjacent to the Gotham Lounge on aft Deck 3, the City Room is a 100-seat conference room that is often used for the ship’s art auctions. Peter Knego Fullscreen Located at the aft end of Decks 3 and 2, the 1,250-seat Bacchus Dining Room is the Carnival Miracle’s main dining venue. The upper level is reserved for “Your Time” dining, where guests can dine when and where they like between 5:45 and 9:30 p.m. Peter Knego Fullscreen Table settings in the Bacchus Dining room include colorful Euro by Vortex brand chargers. Peter Knego Fullscreen Food and service in the Bacchus Dining Room is consistently of a high standard and there is a variety of international cuisine, including a spicy Indian vegetarian meal that changes nightly. Peter Knego Fullscreen Located on forward/port Promenade Deck (2), Carnival’s signature Redfrog Pub was added to the Carnival Miracle in April of 2015. The Caribbean-inspired bar accommodates 135 guests and serves rums and beers. Peter Knego Fullscreen Directly across from the Redfrog Pub on the starboard side of Deck 2, the Joker Card Room seats 20. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Fountainhead Cafe on Deck 2 is the go-to place for a la carte specialty coffees, shakes and cakes. Peter Knego Fullscreen Next to the Fountainhead Cafe on Deck 2, the Fountain Stairs descend from a suite of Deck 3 public areas. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Fun Hub is adjacent to the Fountainhead Cafe on Deck 2 and is a favorite spot for quizzes, games and even a live pianist at varying times of the day. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Sky Box is a brand new, 67-seat sports bar on Deck 2 that was added in April of 2015. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Miracle’s vast Mr. Lucky’s Casino is located on midships Deck 2, accommodating up to 278 guests. The casino has its own bar and a stage for live music. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Shore Excursions Desk is in the port/forward corner of the Metropolis Atrium. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Shore Excursions Desk is in the port/forward corner of the Metropolis Atrium. The Shore Excursions Desk is in the port/forward corner of the Metropolis Atrium. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Metropolis Atrium is a soaring space that spans ten decks upward from the Metropolis Bar at its base. Peter Knego Fullscreen Directly aft of the Metroplis Atrium on the starboard side of Deck 2, the Alchemy Bar, which serves up cocktails made with fresh herbs and other exotic ingredients, is another Carnival signature venue that was added in April of 2015. Peter Knego Fullscreen Frankenstein’s Lab is a double-deck night club on aft Deck 2 that features an oversized “creature” and other Frankenstein motifs, including lightning bolt style lighting effects. Peter Knego Fullscreen Offering two fixed dinner seatings, the lower level of the grape-infused Bacchus Dining Room is located on aft Deck 2. This over-the-top space was conceived by former Carnival architect Joseph Farcus. Peter Knego Fullscreen The Ariadne Room is an annex to the Bacchus Dining Room that seats 86-guests. Peter Knego Fullscreen Used for a number of functions, including the nightly Punchliners Comedy Club, the 348 seat Alice In Wonderland-inspired Mad Hatter’s Ball is located on forward Riviera Deck (1). Peter Knego Fullscreen The Carnival Miracle has five self-service launderettes. Peter Knego Fullscreen Carnival Miracle has twelve accommodation categories. At the top end of the spectrum are six 430-square-foot Penthouse Suites with separate bedrooms and sitting areas. Peter Knego Fullscreen Penthouse Suites have original artworks, a living room nook, bar area and even a dressing area with a walk-in closet. Peter Knego Fullscreen Penthouse Suite bathrooms have granite tilework, double sinks, a toilet and a bidet. Peter Knego Fullscreen Penthouse Suite bathrooms also feature deluxe Jacuzzi tubs. Peter Knego Fullscreen Penthouse Suite balconies are lined in teakwood and are large enough to accommodate two loungers, a small table and two chairs. Peter Knego Fullscreen Located at the stern of the ship, 340-square-foot Vista Suites can be combined with the neighboring balcony stateroom. Peter Knego Fullscreen This is the living room of a Vista Suite. Like the Penthouse Suites, they also feature a private dressing area and walk-in closet. Peter Knego Fullscreen This is the bedroom of a Vista Suite. Peter Knego Fullscreen Vista Suites have wrap-around balconies that overlook the ship’s wake. Peter Knego Fullscreen Ocean Suites are smaller than Penthouse and Vista Suites but have similar amenities, including granite tiled bathrooms with Jacuzzi tubs and walk-in closets. Peter Knego Fullscreen Ocean Suites also have large, teak-lined balconies. Peter Knego Fullscreen Premium Balcony staterooms are smaller than suites but larger than standard balcony cabins. Peter Knego Fullscreen Premium Balcony staterooms feature granite-tiled bathrooms with a shower. Peter Knego Fullscreen Premium Balcony staterooms have wide, teak-lined balconies. Peter Knego Fullscreen Standard Balcony staterooms measure 220-square-feet and have twin or king sized bed configurations. Peter Knego Fullscreen Bathrooms in Balcony, Oceanview and Interior cabins are well designed modular units with sink, toilet, shower and plenty of storage space. Peter Knego Fullscreen This is a balcony on an aft-facing standard Balcony stateroom. Peter Knego Fullscreen Handicap-accessible Balcony staterooms are larger than average and feature wider doors and modified fixtures. Peter Knego Fullscreen Handicap-accessible stateroom bathrooms have roll-in showers with unfolding seats. Peter Knego Fullscreen Handicap-accessible Balcony stateroom balconies have wide doors and ramps on the balcony door sills. Peter Knego Fullscreen Oceanview staterooms are similar to Balcony staterooms but have large picture windows instead of balconies. Peter Knego Fullscreen Interior staterooms generally measure 185-square-feet and come in several configurations, including this comfortable twin. Peter Knego Fullscreen This Interior stateroom accommodates three with an unfolding upper berth. Peter Knego 8 CONNECT 3 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read //usat.ly/1RRpOIr TOP VIDEOS
